blog.name: eros-heartache
blog.title: Eros Heartache
blog.description: 100% NOT here for anyone to validate me, Multifandom shitposter, Hedonist/Libertine, random other shit.... Message from Me: You own your shit, you walk your talk. Its fantastic to be loved and happy, but own the knowlege you can and will be a problematic person to someone. You can be hated with validity and with take ownership of your faults. In the end you will never make yourself anything more than the sum of your life, perceptions and expierance. And that wisdom my loves, Is what makes all the diffence.

summary: did you see michael go off on that person on twitter? i thought i couldn't love him any more, but alas my grinch heart just...
question: did you see michael go off on that person on twitter? i thought i couldn't love him any more, but alas my grinch heart just keeps growing!
answer:
RIGHT, SAME??? Like y’all know how much I am passionate about defending the Deep Literary Merit of fanfic (perhaps some of you don’t know that I have a podcast that’s all about holding up fanfic as something that can be analyzed side-by-side with profic) and it just makes me so happy that we are taking yet another step forward in the progression of mainstream people realizing that Fanfic Is Cool Actually. 

Consider how snide and dismissive and uncomfortable the Sherlock actors were, five years ago. Consider how, fifteen years ago, I wouldn’t have been able to post my fanvids to any account remotely connected to my real name without risking the very real possibility of destroying my reputation and career as a professional fantasy author. Back then, I would have had to nuke all my fanworks from orbit immediately upon getting a book deal, just like so many other people had to.

But… nowadays? Archive Of Our Own is up for a Hugo Award this year, and here’s Michael Sheen publicly retweeting fanart on main and talking about reading fanfic as background for his character and fiercely defending fan creators, using language that indicates he understands on a fundamental level the fanwork-making impetus. And it is just so, so incredible and touching and vindicating.

Finally people begin to understand that a bunch of women and queers loving things out loud and at great volume isn’t a shameful or scary or threatening thing. There’s work still to be done, but we’ve made so much progress already.

Like y’all know how much I am passionate about defending the Deep Literary Merit of fanfic (perhaps some of you don’t know that I have a podcast that’s all about holding up fanfic as something that can be analyzed side-by-side with profic) and it just makes me so happy that we are taking yet another step forward in the progression of mainstream people realizing that Fanfic Is Cool Actually.
